etymologies: late Old English rōt, from Old Norse rót; related to Latin radix, also to wort

definitions: the part of a plant which attaches it to the ground or to a support, typically underground, conveying water and nourishment to the rest of the plant via numerous branches and fibers

examples.text: cacti have deep and spreading roots
a tree root

shortDefinitions: part of plant which attaches it to ground

definitions: the persistent underground part of a plant, especially when fleshy and enlarged and used as a vegetable, e.g. a turnip or carrot

examples.text: you should never wash roots before storing

shortDefinitions: persistent underground part of plant

definitions: any plant grown for its edible root

examples.text: roots like beet and carrot cannot be transplanted

shortDefinitions: any plant grown for such root

definitions: the embedded or basal part of a bodily organ or structure such as a hair, tooth, or nail

examples.text: her hair was fairer at the roots

shortDefinitions: embedded or basal part of bodily organ or structure

definitions: the part of a thing attaching it to a greater or more fundamental whole; the end or base

examples.text: a little lever near the root of the barrel

shortDefinitions: part of thing attaching it to greater or more fundamental whole

definitions: the basic cause, source, or origin of something

examples.text: love of money is the root of all evil
jealousy was at the root of it
the root cause of the problem

shortDefinitions: basic cause, source, or origin of something

definitions: family, ethnic, or cultural origins, especially as the reasons for one's long-standing emotional attachment to a place or community

examples.text: it's always nice to return to my roots

shortDefinitions: family, ethnic, or cultural origins

definitions: denoting or relating to something from a particular ethnic or cultural origin, especially a non-Western one

examples.text: roots music

shortDefinitions: denoting something from particular ethnic or cultural origin

definitions: (in biblical use) a scion; a descendant

examples.text: the root of David

shortDefinitions: (in biblical use) scion

definitions: a morpheme, not necessarily surviving as a word in itself, from which words have been made by the addition of prefixes or suffixes or by other modification

examples.text: many European words stem from this linguistic root
the root form of the word

shortDefinitions: morpheme, not necessarily surviving as word in itself

definitions: the fundamental note of a chord

examples.text: in the sequence the roots of the chords drop by fifths

shortDefinitions: fundamental note of chord

definitions: a number or quantity that when multiplied by itself, typically a specified number of times, gives a specified number or quantity

examples.text: find the cube root of the result

shortDefinitions: number or quantity that when multiplied by itself gives specified number or quantity

definitions: a value of an unknown quantity satisfying a given equation

examples.text: the roots of the equation differ by an integer

shortDefinitions: value of unknown quantity satisfying given equation

definitions: a user account with full and unrestricted access to a system

examples.text: make sure that these files can only be accessed by the root user
I need to log in as root on my system to resolve an issue

shortDefinitions: user account with full and unrestricted access to system

definitions: cause (a plant or cutting) to grow roots

examples.text: root your own cuttings from stock plants

shortDefinitions: cause plant or cutting to grow roots

definitions: (of a plant or cutting) establish roots

examples.text: large trees had rooted in the canal bank

shortDefinitions: (of plant or cutting) establish roots

definitions: establish deeply and firmly

examples.text: vegetarianism is rooted in Indian culture

shortDefinitions: establish deeply

definitions: have as an origin or cause

examples.text: the Latin dubitare is rooted in an Indo-European word

shortDefinitions: have as origin or cause

definitions: cause (someone) to stand immobile through fear or amazement

examples.text: George was rooted to the spot in disbelief
fear rooted me to the spot

shortDefinitions: cause someone to stand immobile

definitions: gain access to the root account of (a smartphone or computer)

examples.text: we explained how to manually root almost any Android device

shortDefinitions: gain access to root account of smartphone or computer

etymologies: Old English wrōtan, of Germanic origin; related to Old English wrōt ‘snout’, German Rüssel ‘snout’, and perhaps ultimately to Latin rodere ‘gnaw’

definitions: (of an animal) turn up the ground with its snout in search of food

examples.text: stray dogs rooting around for bones and scraps

shortDefinitions: turn up ground with its snout in search of food

definitions: search unsystematically through an untidy mass or area; rummage

examples.text: she was rooting through a pile of papers

shortDefinitions: search unsystematically through untidy mass or area

definitions: an act of rooting

examples.text: I have a root through the open drawers

shortDefinitions: act of rooting
